text: <@U167FL70V|leia> has joined the channel

Ok, so I have to say it:  I was thinking about it last night and I’m quickly becoming more and more of a proponent of using QR codes on the keynote slides to bookmark content. Which may not sound _that_ crazy to you all (or maybe it does), but I’ve been a hater on QR codes for years now. However, for this purpose (and the fact that it ties back to the everyone theme of BL=digital ads), I actually think it works quite nicely :grin:. Just my 2 cents
:neutral_face:
haha
What QR app is the best?
is this a comedy routine?
Personally, I like to just write down a page number.

Hear me out though: The major problems with QR codes is 1.) You need to open a seperate app just to read them 2.) The placement of them is usually awful (am I going to capture a QR code on a billboard while driving 60 mph down the free or stand in front of a shop window, etc.) 3.) The value prop is never clearly stated
I did that once.
i'm listening.
I hit a chipmunk! SUCKED
In a controlled environment, the QR reader could be integrated into the app, the placement is static and the value prop is clear
in a controlled environment, why would you want a QR code?
and not just like, a bookmark icon
Because RoS is built in keynote, which Apple makes virtually impossible to tie into their system
thats not a controlled environment
if the QR code is to solve a shortcoming in a framework, then i agree

So we are going to need them to recreate the RoS in the IS scheduler tool for all of our post workshop context, but it’s going to be pretty impossible for a guest to tell us (tell me more about this slide, I’m interested in this slide)\
ultrasonic comms
What are those?
<http://www.copsonic.com/sdk.html>
For example
Basically each slide plays a different tone. The app can "hear" it and get the info it needs
Cool!
The user doesn't have to do anything but wonder "how does this app know what I'm trying to do"
How long has this been out there?
A while. Is used in retail a lot
Pre beacon and now with beacon usually
Looks pretty awesome and way less ugly than QR codes
In something as atomic as a keynote presentation it actually makes a lot of sense
Cause there's no chance of overlapping tones
And you don't have to break user attention much to have them do something
Yeah. And each sound signal can be uploaded as a mp3?
Yeah
Take a peek at audio fingerprinting frameworks for more info
Awesome! Thanks!
Glad I made my 2 am “QR codes could actually work?!” rant public :wink:
